abstract: In King’s latest novel, a teenage boy discovers another world beneath a backyard shed.
snippet: In King’s latest novel, a teenage boy discovers another world beneath a backyard shed.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King is no stranger to the portal fantasy genre, or to the kinds of young, unwitting protagonists who end up traveling to other worlds. In “The Gunslinger,” the first volume of his epic Dark Tower series, King gave us 11-year-old Jake Chambers, who arrives in Roland of Gilead’s world after dying in ours. In “The Talisman,” co-written with Peter Straub, 12-year-old Jack Sawyer “flips” between America and the fantastical Territories on a quest to save his mother’s life. Twenty years later, King and Straub sent Jack on another Territories adventure in “Black House,” this time connecting his story to the Dark Tower books and King’s larger multiverse.

abstract: Siblings can’t see eye to eye on where to put the litter box.
snippet: Siblings can’t see eye to eye on where to put the litter box.
lead_paragraph: Alana writes: My little sister and her cat, Swampy, are living with me for a month. Swampy is an excellent cat, but I would like his litter box in our basement apartment with my sister. She wants it in our living room because she doesn’t think Swampy will “feel welcome” upstairs without it.

abstract: I have deep doubts about the intellectual and social value of schooling.
snippet: I have deep doubts about the intellectual and social value of schooling.
lead_paragraph: I have deep doubts about the intellectual and social value of schooling. My argument in a nutshell: First, everyone leaves school eventually. Second, most of what you learn in school doesn’t matter after graduation. Third, human beings soon forget knowledge they rarely use.

abstract: Many migrant parents believe that American schools promise their children the opportunity for a better life.
snippet: Many migrant parents believe that American schools promise their children the opportunity for a better life.
lead_paragraph: It was a cold day in January 2019, and Heidi, who was 6 years old, was ready for her first day of school in the United States. Her father, Jorge, woke up early to help her with her hair and pack her lunch. Jorge and Heidi had migrated from Guatemala to the United States in 2018. (I am using their first names only because of their vulnerable and changing immigration status.) Upon arrival at the Mexico-U.S. border, they were separated. For more than two months Jorge was in Texas while his daughter was 1,700 miles away in New York City.

abstract: It can be a safe haven for our most vulnerable children.
snippet: It can be a safe haven for our most vulnerable children.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Wilson’s TikTok videos often begin with the back of a little girl’s head. The child’s hair is matted, and Wilson, who works at Butcher-Greene Elementary in Grandview, Mo., begins to gently comb out the snarls. By the end of the videos, which tend to be just a minute or two long, the girl’s hair has been transformed into a beautiful braided style, often with colorful bows adorning it.

abstract: The fashion-turned-furniture designer lets his creativity flow from wherever.
snippet: The fashion-turned-furniture designer lets his creativity flow from wherever.
lead_paragraph: The artist and designer Rogan Gregory often has a spasm of creativity after midnight, shaking off slumber at 1 a.m. or 2 a.m. to take notes or sketch ideas for his furniture and objects. The habit is his version of the “dorveille,” a period of creative wakefulness.

abstract: Of course Serena Williams is confident. She deserves to be. And her opponents know that her improving game and overwhelming crowd support make beating her in this U.S. Open all the more difficult.
snippet: Of course Serena Williams is confident. She deserves to be. And her opponents know that her improving game and overwhelming crowd support make beating her in this U.S. Open all the more difficult.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams is almost 41. She did not play competitive tennis for nearly a year, and it showed — truly it showed — at Wimbledon, in Toronto and in Mason, Ohio, the three tournaments where she made painfully brief appearances this summer before arriving in New York for her farewell U.S. Open.

abstract: In a prime-time speech in Philadelphia, President Biden cast the midterm elections as a choice between his agenda and the extremism of “MAGA Republicans.”
snippet: In a prime-time speech in Philadelphia, President Biden cast the midterm elections as a choice between his agenda and the extremism of “MAGA Republicans.”
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Biden traveled to Independence Hall on Thursday to warn that America's democratic values are under assault by forces of extremism loyal to former President Donald J. Trump, using a prime-time address to define the midterm elections as a “battle for the soul of this nation.”

byline.original: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear

abstract: The play Kenny Pickett made famous has been banned. Defensive holding? Now an automatic first down. And the N.C.A.A. is still trying to rid the game of feigned injuries.
snippet: The play Kenny Pickett made famous has been banned. Defensive holding? Now an automatic first down. And the N.C.A.A. is still trying to rid the game of feigned injuries.
lead_paragraph: For all that does not seem to change in college football — Alabama around the top of the polls, hype about Texas, Kirk Ferentz as Iowa’s coach — the sport’s rule book gets some rewrites and tweaks before every season.

abstract: If politics is the art of the possible, perhaps the biggest silver lining of these past two years has been to redefine what is possible.
snippet: If politics is the art of the possible, perhaps the biggest silver lining of these past two years has been to redefine what is possible.
lead_paragraph: America is often hailed as a land of opportunity, a place where all children, no matter their family background, have the chance to succeed. Data measuring how low-income children tend to fare in adulthood, however, suggest this may be more myth than reality.

abstract: In her new novel, “On the Rooftop,” Margaret Wilkerson Sexton introduces a musical family with wide-ranging visions of happiness.
snippet: In her new novel, “On the Rooftop,” Margaret Wilkerson Sexton introduces a musical family with wide-ranging visions of happiness.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions, and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

abstract: Amazon’s pricey, gorgeous fantasy spectacle delivers what fans expect, but it could thrive by giving them what they don’t.
snippet: Amazon’s pricey, gorgeous fantasy spectacle delivers what fans expect, but it could thrive by giving them what they don’t.
lead_paragraph: What does several hundred million dollars buy?

abstract: Public education requires lessons about history and also contact with and context about other Americans: who we are and what has made us.
snippet: Public education requires lessons about history and also contact with and context about other Americans: who we are and what has made us.
lead_paragraph: Why do we have public schools? To make young people into educated, productive adults, of course. But public schools are also for making Americans. Thus, public education requires lessons about history — the American spirit and its civics — and also contact with and context about other Americans: who we are and what has made us.

byline.original: By Heather C. McGhee and Victor Ray

abstract: All kinds of kids, from all kinds of families — rich, poor and middle class — need more help with reading than they’re getting in school.
snippet: All kinds of kids, from all kinds of families — rich, poor and middle class — need more help with reading than they’re getting in school.
lead_paragraph: The most important thing schools can do is teach children how to read. If you can read, you can learn anything. If you can’t, almost everything in school is difficult. Word problems. Test directions. Biology homework. Everything comes back to reading.

abstract: “Somewhere along the line I liberated myself from the idea that I have to finish every book I start, instantly enlarging my exposure to new kinds of books.,” says the author and illustrator, whose latest picture book is “The Pigeon Will Ride the Roller Coaster!” “A book doesn’t have to be to my taste to be ‘good.’”
snippet: “Somewhere along the line I liberated myself from the idea that I have to finish every book I start, instantly enlarging my exposure to new kinds of books.,” says the author and illustrator, whose latest picture book is “The Pigeon Will Ride the R...
lead_paragraph: It’s a joy to read a few pages in my library in the evenings. Weekend reading outside is also wonderful. But I think I most love a reading lunch with my wife, because we get to chat about what we’ve just read over coffee.

abstract: Max Fisher’s “The Chaos Machine” examines the psychological impacts of technology.
snippet: Max Fisher’s “The Chaos Machine” examines the psychological impacts of technology.
lead_paragraph: In Max Fisher’s authoritative and devastating account of the impacts of social media, “The Chaos Machine,” he repeatedly invokes Stanley Kubrick’s masterpiece “2001: A Space Odyssey.” The 1968 movie, in which a supercomputer coldly kills astronauts on a ship bound for Jupiter, was in Fisher’s thoughts as he researched the book. Its stark, ambiguous aesthetic is perfectly poised between the utopian and the dystopian. And as a story about trying to fix a wayward technology as it hurtles out of control, it is beautifully apt.

abstract: Merit demands excellence and rigor. It is not, as its critics often insist, an elitist, classist or racist value.
snippet: Merit demands excellence and rigor. It is not, as its critics often insist, an elitist, classist or racist value.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, as a 5-foot-0 teen at Morgantown High School in the foothills of West Virginia’s Appalachians, I stepped forward at our annual sports award ceremony to claim an honor: female athlete with the highest G.P.A. A boy named Michael Roh, who won the male athlete award, towered over me at 6-foot-6. He’d been my academic rival since middle school. But on this day, we both smiled. We had both ascended based on hard work and merit.

abstract: A ban on single-use plastic and paper bags in grocery stores had an unintended effect: Delivery services switched to heavy, reusable sacks — lots of them.
snippet: A ban on single-use plastic and paper bags in grocery stores had an unintended effect: Delivery services switched to heavy, reusable sacks — lots of them.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Kramaritsch of Roxbury, N.J., has 46 bags just sitting in her garage. Brian Otto has 101 of them, so many that he’s considering sewing them into blackout curtains for his baby’s bedroom. (So far, that idea has gone nowhere.) Lili Mannuzza in Whippany has 74.

abstract: Since the Williams sisters first burst into tennis in the 1990s, their legacy has been tied to one another. They will play doubles in perhaps the final tournament of their careers.
snippet: Since the Williams sisters first burst into tennis in the 1990s, their legacy has been tied to one another. They will play doubles in perhaps the final tournament of their careers.
lead_paragraph: The Williams sisters. They are the yin to the other’s yang. Starkly different in disposition but tied together by history and sisterly bond.

abstract: A new study digs into what is most important to young adults ages 18 to 25.
snippet: A new study digs into what is most important to young adults ages 18 to 25.
lead_paragraph: Jumping into adulthood has been tough of late. When the coronavirus pandemic hit, young adults scurried back to their parents’ or grandparents’ homes. Roughly 80 percent of them were members of Generation Z, those born in the late 1990s through the early 2000s; a third of that generation is still living there today. Now, inflation and competition for rentals have created more obstacles to moving out.

abstract: “The U.S. and the Holocaust,” coming to PBS Sept. 18, examines the reasons behind the country’s inadequate response to Germany’s persecution of Jews.
snippet: “The U.S. and the Holocaust,” coming to PBS Sept. 18, examines the reasons behind the country’s inadequate response to Germany’s persecution of Jews.
lead_paragraph: A new documentary about the Holocaust opens with photos of perhaps the most familiar faces from that dark chapter of history: those of Anne Frank and her family, whose story has been read or seen by millions around the world.

abstract: Our democracy sprouts in the nursery of public schools — where students grapple, together, with our messy history and learn to negotiate differences.
snippet: Our democracy sprouts in the nursery of public schools — where students grapple, together, with our messy history and learn to negotiate differences.
lead_paragraph: For the majority of human history, most people didn’t go to school. Formal education was a privilege for the Alexander the Greats of the world, who could hire Aristotles as private tutors.

abstract: The painting, known as “Swing Girl” and “Girl on a Swing,” and the building it adorns are headed to the auction block with the hope that the sale price will reach $30 million.
snippet: The painting, known as “Swing Girl” and “Girl on a Swing,” and the building it adorns are headed to the auction block with the hope that the sale price will reach $30 million.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, while in town for the Los Angeles premiere of his documentary “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” the British street artist Banksy left a gift for fans: a mural of a girl on a swing, dangling beneath the five-foot red “A” of the word “PARKING” on a gritty downtown lot.

abstract: Cotton forms the foundation of Caralarga’s objects and fashions.
snippet: Cotton forms the foundation of Caralarga’s objects and fashions.
lead_paragraph: The way Ana Holschneider explained it, everything Caralarga makes is jewelry. It all depends on how you wear it.

abstract: A successful deal to restrain Iran’s nuclear program would mean that Washington lifts tough sanctions on Iran’s oil and gas exports. But it may already be too late for that to help this winter.
snippet: A successful deal to restrain Iran’s nuclear program would mean that Washington lifts tough sanctions on Iran’s oil and gas exports. But it may already be too late for that to help this winter.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As Russia squeezes Europe on supplies of natural gas and Europe readies an embargo on Russian oil, some are looking for help from Iran. That is, of course, if and when Tehran and Washington agree to revive the 2015 nuclear deal, lifting tough economic sanctions on Iran that have limited its ability to export energy.

byline.original: By Steven Erlanger and Stanley Reed

abstract: When the “Crime Junkie” co-host’s debut novel came out, it didn’t seem real until she signed copies to the sound of boarding announcements.
snippet: When the “Crime Junkie” co-host’s debut novel came out, it didn’t seem real until she signed copies to the sound of boarding announcements.
lead_paragraph: When Ashley Flowers strolled into Hudson News in Indianapolis International Airport and spotted a book with her name on the cover, she knew she had arrived.

abstract: A look at design-world events, products and people.
snippet: A look at design-world events, products and people.
lead_paragraph: For the German-born designer Jan Kath, now living in Chiang Mai, Thailand, rugs are not just decorative objects; they also reflect global politics. His “Rug Bombs” exhibition of 11 handknotted works at the Alte Brüderkirche, a church in Kassel, Germany, follows a modern tradition by artisans in troubled countries of weaving images of violence and warfare into textiles.

abstract: She’s landed her dream role in “Funny Girl.” Now she’s tasked with rescuing the faltering Broadway show and proving that she is not the person she once was.
snippet: She’s landed her dream role in “Funny Girl.” Now she’s tasked with rescuing the faltering Broadway show and proving that she is not the person she once was.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, Lea Michele was sulking in her “Spring Awakening” dressing room, heartbroken over a guy, when the Broadway show’s director offered her a bit of advice.

abstract: School is for nurturing children’s innate talents and helping them figure out where those gifts, necessarily diverse, fit in the whole.
snippet: School is for nurturing children’s innate talents and helping them figure out where those gifts, necessarily diverse, fit in the whole.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the first five years of my older daughter’s life, I watched her dance through the clover, climb trees, puddle jump and play her way through the day. As she stood on the threshold to kindergarten, I pictured her stuck inside at a desk, cut off from her relationship to the wild, and my stomach sank. I believe that school is for nurturing children’s innate talents and helping them figure out where those gifts, necessarily diverse, fit in the whole. The school system, by contrast, tends to produce a monoculture. Despite the heroic efforts of many thoughtful, caring teachers, public school mostly prepares children to be obedient workers and fails millions of students who don’t fit the mold.

abstract: Eric Egan’s interior design studio upholds couture traditions with exquisite — but far from stodgy — details for the home.
snippet: Eric Egan’s interior design studio upholds couture traditions with exquisite — but far from stodgy — details for the home.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Across the street from the medieval Sforzesco Castle, up an iron cage elevator and through a dark-paneled foyer, sits a showroom that is a shrine to the bespoke with a particularly Italian attitude.

abstract: Survivors describe the defining atrocity of the war in Ukraine.
snippet: Survivors describe the defining atrocity of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Elyzaveta Fatayeva was sitting on a blanket in the basement, next to her boyfriend, when the theater exploded above her. The whole building convulsed, and she with it. Her ears filled with a tremendous crashing sound. Her eyes squeezed shut for a moment. When they opened, the air was a cloud of masonry dust. She gasped it in and choked. When her breath returned, there was a ringing in her ears. Then silence. Then people around her coughing. Then yelling.

abstract: The pandemic may have left some gaps in the urban fabric, but a neighborhood-by-neighborhood rundown of new restaurants and art events reveals that recovery is well underway.
snippet: The pandemic may have left some gaps in the urban fabric, but a neighborhood-by-neighborhood rundown of new restaurants and art events reveals that recovery is well underway.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 9, 2020, the Seattle Asian Art Museum reopened after a three-year, $56 million renovation and expansion that transformed the look, feel and reach of the venerable institution. Five weeks later, the first round of statewide Covid lockdowns shuttered the place. “It was heartbreaking for me and my colleagues,” said Foong Ping, the Foster Foundation Curator of Chinese Art at the museum. “It was shoulder to shoulder in the newly imagined galleries — then silence.”

abstract: New books on gnarly trees with pedigrees, lost Miami buildings and vintage construction toys, along with a deep dive into African textiles.
snippet: New books on gnarly trees with pedigrees, lost Miami buildings and vintage construction toys, along with a deep dive into African textiles.
lead_paragraph: The landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted, in laying out thousands of 19th-century parkland acres, specified fine points down to the rock textures. The serendipities of age keep improving his designs. “Olmsted Trees” (Hirmer/University of Chicago Press, $40, 160 pp.), by the photographer Stanley Greenberg, celebrates bark that resembles barnacles, lizard skin or cooled lava. (The book includes essays by Tom Avermaete, an urban design professor; Kevin Baker, a writer; and Mindy Thompson Fullilove, a social psychiatrist.) Torqued trunks have knobs and cavities that evoke human eyes and animal snouts, while roots bulge like giant paws kneading the earth. The trees shrug off signs of human intervention, dwarfing fencing and playground equipment, and appearing unfazed by carvings of lovers’ initials.

abstract: At 83, the filmmaker behind “Cooley High” and “Car Wash” may be the longest-working Black director in history. His own story is a Hollywood epic.
snippet: At 83, the filmmaker behind “Cooley High” and “Car Wash” may be the longest-working Black director in history. His own story is a Hollywood epic.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Schultz began work on his first film, in 1971, there was no road map for a lengthy career as a Black director in Hollywood. The first two studio movies to employ Black directors — Gordon Parks’s “The Learning Tree” (1969) and Ossie Davis’s “Cotton Comes to Harlem” (1970) — had only relatively recently left theaters. And the movement that would soon be known as Blaxploitation — mimicking the work of Davis, Parks and the trailblazing independent filmmaker Melvin Van Peebles — did little to suggest a promising future.

abstract: As Apple prepares to unveil new models next week, the smart watch has found an unexpected audience: children as young as 5.
snippet: As Apple prepares to unveil new models next week, the smart watch has found an unexpected audience: children as young as 5.
lead_paragraph: Florian Fangohr waffled for about a year over whether to buy an Apple Watch SE as a gift. The smart watch cost $279, and he worried that its recipient would immediately break or lose it. In May, he decided the benefits outweighed the costs and bought the gadget.

byline.original: By Kalley Huang and Brian X. Chen

abstract: For three-quarters of a century, the $1.7 trillion global fashion industry has found opportunity in home furnishings.
snippet: For three-quarters of a century, the $1.7 trillion global fashion industry has found opportunity in home furnishings.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Lauren Home. Fendi Casa. Louis Vuitton’s Art of Living. Fashion companies cannot seem to resist the lure of household objects.

abstract: Long cut off from the continent’s grid, Portugal and Spain built a system based on imports and alternatives like solar that is the envy of fellow European Union nations.
snippet: Long cut off from the continent’s grid, Portugal and Spain built a system based on imports and alternatives like solar that is the envy of fellow European Union nations.
lead_paragraph: Portugal has no coal mines, oil wells or gas fields. Its impressive hydropower production has been crippled this year by drought. And its long-running disconnect from the rest of Europe’s energy network has earned the country its status as an “energy island.”

abstract: Worried about geopolitical tensions and stung by pandemic shutdowns, Google, Apple and others are moving some work to nearby countries.
snippet: Worried about geopolitical tensions and stung by pandemic shutdowns, Google, Apple and others are moving some work to nearby countries.
lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, Apple and Google will unveil their latest generation of smartphones, jockeying to distinguish the new devices from previous models. But one of the most significant changes will go largely unnoticed by consumers: Some of these phones will not be made in China.

byline.original: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Tripp Mickle

abstract: For those who crave efficiency, some websites tackle wedding planning with an add-to-cart approach.
snippet: For those who crave efficiency, some websites tackle wedding planning with an add-to-cart approach.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long after Samantha Tully and Colton Sykes began planning their nuptials before the process became overwhelming.

abstract: New novels from Stephen King, Elizabeth Strout and Maggie O’Farrell; stories by Ling Ma and David Means; and plenty more.
snippet: New novels from Stephen King, Elizabeth Strout and Maggie O’Farrell; stories by Ling Ma and David Means; and plenty more.
lead_paragraph: The author, a civil rights activist, traces the roots of political dissatisfaction among many Black voters and examines the ways she believes Democratic Party has abandoned them.

abstract: It can be a short step from a runway look to a home furnishing — especially if the designer has a foot in both worlds.
snippet: It can be a short step from a runway look to a home furnishing — especially if the designer has a foot in both worlds.
lead_paragraph: When you ask Raf Simons, the co-creative director of Prada, why he abandoned his intended career as a furniture designer for fashion, he has two words to say: “Martin Margiela” (referring to the avant-garde couturier and fellow Belgian). But when Mr. Simons returned to his furnishing roots recently to create a Shaker-inspired storage system that mounts on a wall, it hardly seemed like a step away.

abstract: What is school really for? Students at Oakland’s Fremont High answer this question with their cameras.
snippet: What is school really for? Students at Oakland’s Fremont High answer this question with their cameras.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — School is a community, a common place to gain relationships. School is for social interactions and learning to become an active member of society.

abstract: “It’s a bit of fashion, a bit of design, but I see it more like a book about paintings,” said the author, Benoit Pierre Emery.
snippet: “It’s a bit of fashion, a bit of design, but I see it more like a book about paintings,” said the author, Benoit Pierre Emery.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Benoit Pierre Emery bought a silk Christian Dior scarf from the 1970s for about $30 on eBay in 2001, little did he realize it would be the seed of a collection that would grow to more than 10,000 pieces over two decades and lead to a book to be published later this year.

abstract: Once the head of women’s wear for Stella McCartney and Jil Sander, Leena Similu has taken a 180-degree turn into ceramics.
snippet: Once the head of women’s wear for Stella McCartney and Jil Sander, Leena Similu has taken a 180-degree turn into ceramics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Leena Similu leads the way from her porch to her backyard, in a hilly portion of Silver Lake. Outside, she passes a large electric kiln, a potter’s wheel and a shelf of grimacing and grinning figures that have come to define her ceramics work. Near the back door of her house, a child’s scooter lies on its side.

abstract: Questions on filling a home, carving out guest quarters, deciding whether to choose marble and finding a decent-looking light switch.
snippet: Questions on filling a home, carving out guest quarters, deciding whether to choose marble and finding a decent-looking light switch.
lead_paragraph: I recently relocated and took with me basically nothing. What’s the best strategy to fill up an apartment? Should I buy everything at once? Or wait and build it out?

abstract: Edwin Díaz’s entrance music has been a sensation this season, and the Australian trumpet player appearing in person made it that much better.
snippet: Edwin Díaz’s entrance music has been a sensation this season, and the Australian trumpet player appearing in person made it that much better.
lead_paragraph: Edwin Díaz’s entrance music has been a sensation this season, and the Australian trumpet player appearing in person made it that much better.

abstract: Jacob deGrom dominated, Brandon Nimmo made a catch to remember and Timmy Trumpet played a live version of Edwin Díaz’s entrance song during a thrilling win.
snippet: Jacob deGrom dominated, Brandon Nimmo made a catch to remember and Timmy Trumpet played a live version of Edwin Díaz’s entrance song during a thrilling win.
lead_paragraph: On a shelf in his spare locker at Citi Field, Brandon Nimmo has a baseball with a series of markings by Wayne Kirby, the Mets’ first base coach. Kirby noted the data from a stellar play Nimmo made earlier this summer, inscribing it: “Best Catch 2022.”

abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev set out to reform the Soviet Union. But the social and economic forces he unleashed ended up destroying it.
snippet: Mikhail S. Gorbachev set out to reform the Soviet Union. But the social and economic forces he unleashed ended up destroying it.
lead_paragraph: Few leaders have had as profound an effect on their time as Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, who died this week at 91.

byline.original: By Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Jessica Cheung, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood

abstract: Why NASA wants to go back now.
snippet: Why NASA wants to go back now.
lead_paragraph: Human beings will soon walk on the moon again, if NASA gets its way.

abstract: The film, about a Russian intelligence officer’s covert mission at the end of World War II, begins on a suspenseful note, but the tension soon dissipates.
snippet: The film, about a Russian intelligence officer’s covert mission at the end of World War II, begins on a suspenseful note, but the tension soon dissipates.
lead_paragraph: “Burial” begins suspensefully enough. It opens in 1991 at the London home of a Russian Jewish woman, Anna (Harriet Walter), as she watches TV news of Mikhail S. Gorbachev’s resignation as the Soviet president.

abstract: A team of African mercenaries encounters supernatural foes in this fable-like adventure.
snippet: A team of African mercenaries encounters supernatural foes in this fable-like adventure.
lead_paragraph: Revenge, trauma, child exploitation and environmental degradation — all of these, to one extent or another, undergird the feverish momentum of “Saloum,” a picture that proceeds with more visual brio than narrative clarity.

abstract: Set in Paris in the 1960s, the film tells the story of two irrepressible lovers, and their young son, whose tale turns tragic.
snippet: Set in Paris in the 1960s, the film tells the story of two irrepressible lovers, and their young son, whose tale turns tragic.
lead_paragraph: Régis Roinsard’s “Waiting for Bojangles,” based on the novel by Olivier Bourdeaut, is a film so unabashedly romantic that it could only be French. It tells the story of two boundless, irrepressible lovers, Georges (Romain Duris) and Camile (Virginie Efira), and the life they share in Paris in the 1960s with their young son, Gary (Solan Machado-Graner).

abstract: In this documentary about his life and career, the tennis player John McEnroe, known for his temper, doesn’t bother trying to apologize for his behavior.
snippet: In this documentary about his life and career, the tennis player John McEnroe, known for his temper, doesn’t bother trying to apologize for his behavior.
lead_paragraph: John McEnroe knows it’s too late to apologize. In “McEnroe,” a new documentary chronicling his meteoric rise in the world of tennis, the champion who still holds more titles than any other male player certainly expresses regret over his past behavior, both on the court and off. In the contemporary interviews that frame the documentary, written and directed by Barney Douglas, McEnroe is wise enough to know a “sorry” won’t cut it.

abstract: A documentary examines race in football via Colin Kaepernick’s career.
snippet: A documentary examines race in football via Colin Kaepernick’s career.
lead_paragraph: In the past, when people talked about football heroes, both collegiate and professional, they meant white men. When the game became more integrated, after World War II, a racist myth among some fans held that Black players were good for muscle, while strategic thinking was the domain of white quarterbacks and coaches.

abstract: Apple, Google and Microsoft are among the technology firms looking to shift some of their manufacturing out of China.
snippet: Apple, Google and Microsoft are among the technology firms looking to shift some of their manufacturing out of China.
lead_paragraph: This month, Apple is expected to release the iPhone 14. Beyond rumors, little is known about what the crew from Cupertino, Calif., has planned for the company’s newest version of its nearly ubiquitous smartphone.

byline.original: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Bernhard Warner, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

abstract: Pavel Filatiev has been greeted as a hero by some in the West but is seen as a scourge in his native country for criticizing what he called Russia’s “terrible war.”
snippet: Pavel Filatiev has been greeted as a hero by some in the West but is seen as a scourge in his native country for criticizing what he called Russia’s “terrible war.”
lead_paragraph: He wrote a book describing a Russian military so ill-prepared when it invaded Ukraine that he didn’t know his unit had entered the country until he  awoke to the sound of artillery fire.

byline.original: By Dan Bilefsky and Ivan Nechepurenko

abstract: Workers at Bernheimer Architecture said they hoped to prompt changes to industrywide problems like long hours and low pay.
snippet: Workers at Bernheimer Architecture said they hoped to prompt changes to industrywide problems like long hours and low pay.
lead_paragraph: A union campaign dating back two years and involving workers at several New York-based architecture firms has notched its first victory.

abstract: Take on Mads Andersen in a recreation of a Kvika Reykjavik Open game in Iceland, 2022. Solve for the best series of moves.
snippet: Take on Mads Andersen in a recreation of a Kvika Reykjavik Open game in Iceland, 2022. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. There is one new puzzle left in this limited series, published each week on Thursdays. Play previous Chess Replay puzzles here.

abstract: What the data tells us about how people play the game.
snippet: What the data tells us about how people play the game.
lead_paragraph: The internet is full of advice about the best first guess to use for Wordle, the New York Times game in which players have to figure out the five-letter word of the day in six tries.

abstract: Finally.
snippet: Finally.
lead_paragraph: Begone, typos and grammar mistakes! Begone, fat-fingered auto corrected slip-ups and textual despair! The edit button is coming to Twitter.

abstract: The Golden State is one of only five regions in the world with a Mediterranean-type climate.
snippet: The Golden State is one of only five regions in the world with a Mediterranean-type climate.

abstract: Plus: a new hotel on Kastellorizo in Greece, arboreal wallpaper and more recommendations from T Magazine.
snippet: Plus: a new hotel on Kastellorizo in Greece, arboreal wallpaper and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Though not a duet, Elton John’s latest project is a harmony of sorts. An avid collector of black-and-white photography, the singer has handpicked 50 Peter Hujar prints for an exhibition at San Francisco’s Fraenkel Gallery. Opening next week, “Peter Hujar curated by Elton John” showcases the photographer’s breadth of subjects, which range from seascapes to beefcake to pets. “I’d long wanted to invite a formidable guest curator to dig into Hujar’s work,” says Jeffrey Fraenkel, who’s represented the artist’s estate since the early 2000s. “I came up with about a half dozen names, mostly writers and visual artists, but the idea of Elton seemed unbeatable.” Besides the fact that John has acquired 15 works by Hujar since 2011, the union made emotional sense to Fraenkel. “Hujar’s work focused on the [queer] cultural scene, male erotica and other issues that overlap with Elton’s interests,” says Fraenkel. Hujar is perhaps best known for his images of members of the cultural vanguard of 1970s and ’80s New York — among them Fran Lebowitz, Susan Sontag and David Wojnarowicz, who was Hujar’s partner. John made a point of choosing some of the photographer’s less-seen portraits, including those variously depicting a young Stevie Wonder, a middle-aged Peggy Lee and the Warhol acolyte Jackie Curtis in her open casket. “The show doesn’t shy away from the tough pictures about illness or death, which are main components of Hujar’s work,” says Fraenkel. Hujar himself died of complications from AIDS in 1987. Fittingly, all proceeds from the show’s first two sales will go to the Elton John AIDS Foundation. On view from Sept. 8 through Oct. 22, fraenkelgallery.com.

abstract: In “Breathless,” David Quammen explores the predictable lead-up to the global Covid pandemic, and the frantic, belated attempts to stop it.
snippet: In “Breathless,” David Quammen explores the predictable lead-up to the global Covid pandemic, and the frantic, belated attempts to stop it.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody,” Donald Trump claimed in a March 2020 address, “had any idea.” He was talking about the Covid virus — which had, seemingly overnight, sparked a global pandemic. In his compelling and terrifying new book, “Breathless: The Scientific Race to Defeat a Deadly Virus,” the veteran science journalist David Quammen demonstrates just how much was known — and expected — by infectious disease scientists long before patrons of the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market fell ill in December 2019 with a pneumonia-like virus.

abstract: In most cases, a co-op board has enormous latitude to approve or deny the transfer of a unit’s shares and proprietary lease.
snippet: In most cases, a co-op board has enormous latitude to approve or deny the transfer of a unit’s shares and proprietary lease.
lead_paragraph: Q: My spouse and I purchased a studio apartment in a New York City co-op for our adult son, who has special needs and is able to live independently with the support of an agency. We recently asked the co-op board to allow us to transfer the property to an irrevocable trust, so that when we die he will still have a place to live. The board denied our request. Now we are in a quandary. Our son cannot inherit property directly or he will no longer be able to receive the government benefits that support him. How do we manage this situation?

That’s why horror is the perfect genre for young readers. The form is filled with heightened emotions, pulse-pounding terrors and the exquisite agonies of firsts — and lasts, because this is horror, after all.

abstract: Nineteen days and more than 150 shows later, we’ve made it to Paris.
snippet: Nineteen days and more than 150 shows later, we’ve made it to Paris.
lead_paragraph: Outside the fashion shows of the past month, the crowds have been crackling with an energy that’s been missing for years. The streets of New York were ecstatic. In London, the mood was initially subdued, dampened by the death of Queen Elizabeth II, but the city made a spirited rally on its final day. Milan, on the other hand, can always be counted on to dress the part. Italians have a way of turning out for the things they are proudest of — Ferrari, Prada, Gucci. (In Milan, the fashion-obsessed accessorize almost exclusively with Italian brands.) It’s a sportier affair than other city’s fashion weeks but also a strange, beautiful mess. You can’t catch a taxi to save your life, but it’s not Italy if it’s not a little discombobulated.

abstract: Amid the bluster and veiled threats, the president made three distinct points that form a blueprint for war and peace.
snippet: Amid the bluster and veiled threats, the president made three distinct points that form a blueprint for war and peace.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s speech on Friday, in which he formally proclaimed the annexation of four Ukrainian regions, was many things: a distorted history lecture, a rather tedious enumeration of supposed Western sins, an airing of grievances and a vaunting of power. For all the rhetorical flourish — accusing Western elites of Satanism, for example — it was in many ways a typical address from Mr. Putin.

abstract: A court that does not keep the public’s trust cannot perform its critical role in American government.
snippet: A court that does not keep the public’s trust cannot perform its critical role in American government.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s authority within the American political system is both immense and fragile. Somebody has to provide the last word in interpreting the Constitution, and — this is the key — to do so in a way that is seen as fair and legitimate by the people at large.

abstract: The case for a progressive levy on consumption.
snippet: The case for a progressive levy on consumption.
lead_paragraph: Inflation often begins as a mismatch of supply and demand. But if people get accustomed to prices rising, then inflation becomes about expectations. And so the task of ending it grows fuzzier: You need to use policy not just to manage the economy but also to alter psychology. The arid language of economics obscures the brutality this demands. You need to hit the economy hard enough to cow everyone who makes decisions within it.

abstract: Aerial imagery taken before and after Hurricane Ian made landfall revealed the extent of the damage to parts of Florida’s Gulf Coast.
snippet: Aerial imagery taken before and after Hurricane Ian made landfall revealed the extent of the damage to parts of Florida’s Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: In some areas of southwest Florida, Hurricane Ian left barely a trace of what once stood before. Homes along the coast were reduced to splinters, with only faint hints of their foundations visible. From above, a bridge appeared erased by a violent brushstroke of sand, water and debris. The coastline is scarred with deep gashes of sand.

abstract: It’s time for Indigenous voices to lead the climate fight.
snippet: It’s time for Indigenous voices to lead the climate fight.
lead_paragraph: The natural resources that Indigenous peoples depend on are inextricably linked to their identities, cultures and livelihoods. Even relatively small changes in temperature or rainfall can make their lands more susceptible to rising sea levels, droughts and forest fires. As the climate crisis escalates, activists fighting to protect what remain of the world’s forests are at risk of being persecuted by their governments — and even at risk of death.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seven Americans who had been held captive in Venezuela for years were on their way home Saturday after President Biden agreed to grant clemency to two nephews of Cilia Flores, Venezuela’s first lady, officials said. The men had been sentenced in 2017 to 18 years in prison for conspiring to smuggle cocaine into the United States.

This is her second Times puzzle after a 2018 debut, but she has made a few attempts that didn’t quite succeed, and she jokes that  “I am working on a book I am going to call ‘Best Puzzles Rejected by The New York Times.’”

abstract: Reporters often have little time to prepare before they set out to cover a blaze. To mitigate risk, they adhere to their own guidelines and lean on the experience of others.
snippet: Reporters often have little time to prepare before they set out to cover a blaze. To mitigate risk, they adhere to their own guidelines and lean on the experience of others.
lead_paragraph: One morning in November 2018, Jim Wilson was on a three-hour drive to Paradise, Calif., to cover the Camp fire, which would turn out to be the deadliest fire in California history. The fire had just ripped through 17 miles of wooded foothills in 12 hours, catching Paradise by surprise. Mr. Wilson, a New York Times photographer based in Oakland, was going through a checklist in his head. He had packed his fire-resistant Nomex clothing, his helmet and an emergency fire blanket. But what about the things he couldn’t anticipate?

abstract: The country’s long economic decline has been one of the main forces sending Iranians into the streets over the past two weeks to demand change.
snippet: The country’s long economic decline has been one of the main forces sending Iranians into the streets over the past two weeks to demand change.
lead_paragraph: When Nader, a 41-year-old construction company employee in Tehran, shops for groceries, he constantly adjusts his list as he wanders the aisles, double-checking prices and factoring them into his budget. His basket keeps shrinking as inflation surges: A year ago, he gave up red meat, then chicken.

snippet: In a gathering Cold War atmosphere, American officials are gaming out responses should Russia resort to battlefield nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time since the Cuban Missile Crisis in October 1962, top Russian officials are making explicit nuclear threats and officials in Washington are gaming out scenarios should President Vladimir V. Putin decide to use a tactical nuclear weapon to make up for the failings of Russian troops in Ukraine.

byline.original: By David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes

abstract: In “The Rupture Tense,” Jenny Xie looks at silence surrounding the Cultural Revolution and explores its lasting impact on her own family.
snippet: In “The Rupture Tense,” Jenny Xie looks at silence surrounding the Cultural Revolution and explores its lasting impact on her own family.
lead_paragraph: William Butler Yeats once pictured himself as a golden bird perched on a golden bough, singing to ancient lords and ladies “of what is past, or passing, or to come.” Western civilization has long imagined the fullness of time as a three-act drama with a beginning, a middle and an end; but the end of “Sailing to Byzantium” reveals that “what is past,” or “passing,” or “to come” eludes any simple grammar of the past, present and future. Even now, I’m writing this sentence not in the simple present, but in the present continuous.

abstract: In “The Hero of This Book,” Elizabeth McCracken plays with the usual novelistic conventions.
snippet: In “The Hero of This Book,” Elizabeth McCracken plays with the usual novelistic conventions.
lead_paragraph: When is a memoir not a memoir? Maybe when the writer insists that it is not. “Perhaps you fear writing a memoir, reasonably,” Elizabeth McCracken writes at the beginning of her soulful, melancholy novel, “The Hero of This Book,” about a writer reminiscing about and missing her recently deceased mother.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California has just signed legislation that would require social media companies to make sure new products won’t be harmful to minors. The focus is on Big Tech and social media apps like Facebook, Instagram and TikTok. Flying under the radar are video games even though kids in the United States spend much more time playing video games than engaging in social media, according to a recent Common Sense Media report.

abstract: In “Bully Market,” Jamie Fiore Higgins describes being seduced, and ultimately repelled, by nearly two high-flying decades at Goldman Sachs.
snippet: In “Bully Market,” Jamie Fiore Higgins describes being seduced, and ultimately repelled, by nearly two high-flying decades at Goldman Sachs.
lead_paragraph: “Do What You Love, the Money Will Follow” is the title of a popular, rainbow-covered self-help book published in 1988. “Bully Market,” the new memoir by Jamie Fiore Higgins, a former Goldman Sachs managing director, is clad in unambiguous blood red, suggesting rather that if you do what you hate, the money will chase you down a dark alleyway and throttle you. Maybe eventually it will release you to self-awareness, but not without first inducing temporary blindness.

abstract: Wall Street volatility continued. Tallying the costs of Hurricane Ian has just begun. And a report on the strength of the job market is coming this week.
snippet: Wall Street volatility continued. Tallying the costs of Hurricane Ian has just begun. And a report on the strength of the job market is coming this week.
lead_paragraph: The new British government’s announcement last week that it planned to make drastic tax cuts sent markets tumbling, the pound sinking and the Bank of England scrambling to restore some calm. The panic stemmed from fear that the tax and spending measures proposed by Britain’s recently appointed prime minister, Liz Truss, would add to soaring inflation in the country, running up against the central bank’s efforts to rein it in. Ms. Truss’s government argues that cutting taxes will stimulate investments and that the benefits will buoy the rest of the economy — but investors do not appear convinced. Their unease rippled throughout Europe and to the United States, where benchmark indexes slid. The pound hit its lowest recorded point, creeping near parity with the dollar. On Wednesday, the Bank of England stepped in, saying it will undertake large-scale purchases of British government bonds in the coming weeks to “restore orderly market conditions.” Its forceful intervention pushed the pound back up slightly and helped markets regain some of their losses.

abstract: RIO DE JANEIRO — Since Brazil’s high-stakes presidential race began last year, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s former leftist president, had led the polls by a wide margin. abstract: Everyone’s eyes are on Benjamin Netanyahu as Israelis head back to the polls. It’s the Supreme Court they should be most worried about.

lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel’s election this week is being touted as a new referendum on an old leader — former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is standing trial on corruption charges and is attempting yet another political comeback. But the country faces a much deeper, more worrisome concern: Israel’s judicial branch is on trial and with it Israel’s best hope for democracy.

abstract: The country has a profound story to tell.
snippet: The country has a profound story to tell.
lead_paragraph: How did people imagine Ukraine before Feb. 24, 2022? If pressed, some might have conjured mail-order brides and shaven-head gangsters roaming one big post-Soviet Chernobyl. But most probably didn’t think even that; instead, they didn’t imagine Ukraine at all. The country popped up on most people’s radar only in connection to Western political scandals and Russian war making. Few Westerners visited it, and those who did might have concluded — as one Western journalist confessed to me recently — that “Ukraine was just like Russia but without all the crap.”
